resources.string: Allen was an American computer scientist. She did revolutionary work in optimizing compilers and became the first woman to win both the IBM Fellow and the Turing Award. She worked on a programming language named Alpha while working for the National Security Agency. She worked with a fellow researcher to write a series of papers on optimizing compilers. She also led IBM in developing parallel computing and helped develop software for the IBM Blue Gene Project.

Allen was born in Peru, New York, near Lake Champlain. She was the oldest of her six siblings. Her mother taught in an elementary school and her father was a farmer. She got early elementary education in a single room school house (one mile away from her residence) and then went to a local high school. She was very influenced by her math teacher as a child and went on for becoming a math teacher herself. She taught math for two years at the same high school she had attended later in her life.

For four years, Allen attended the New York State College for Teachers. There, she earned a bachelor of arts in mathematics and minored in physics and education credits. Allen moved to Columbia for some summer courses after this as she realized that she would need a masters degree to become a full teacher. After Columbia, she went to the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor for her masters in mathematics. There, she also took some computer science courses and learned how to program an IBM 650 from Bernard Galler (co-developer of the MAD programming language and President of the ACM). Later in her life, she received six honorary Doctor of Science degrees from six different universities and a Doctor of Engineering degree from University of Notre Dame.

Allen worked for the IBM Corporation and taught FORTRAN to company engineers. She designed and managed the compiler for the Stretch/Harvest computer. Stretch was one of the first supercomputers, and Harvest was a coprocessor that had been designed for the US National Security Agency to decrypt secret messages. Allen designed a compiler framework to handle FORTRAN, Autocoder, and Alpha (3 language compilers). She joined Project Y which included another set of cutting-edge advances in the design of computer systems. She represented programs within the compiler as graphs instead of a sequence of statements so hidden properties of the code could be discovered. Allen then worked on IBM Future Systems project to revolutionize systems and worked on the Experimental Compiler Systems project to support multiple programming languages. Her last big project was IBM PTRAN, a system to compile FORTRAN programs on parallel computer architectures.
